Radiology-Pathology fusion for lung cancer diagnosis and prognosis: Working on development of fused histologic and imaging descriptors-based AI system for prediction of response to immunotherapy in non small-cell lung cancers. In particular, working on combining learning paradigms (deep learning and conventional feature engineering) to understand the spatial arrangement of lymphocytes, morphology of nuclei and their association with CT imaging characteristics in the tumor micro-environment.

Ophthalmic image analysis for therapeutic response assessment: Developing a machine learning pipeline for assessment of the impact of anti-VEGF therapy on retinal vascular dynamics and outer retinal integrity using fundus images and OCT. The pipeline involves segmentation of primitives such as blood vessels, exudates and microaneurysms, computing tortuosity of vessels and using graph theory to assess clinical outcome.

Chair and Professor Department of Biomedical Informatics

After two and a half years of planning, the Emory Department of Biomedical Informatics  (DBMI), also led by Saltz  was inaugurated  April  2011. The Biomedical Informatics Department provides a home for Biomedical Informatics in the Emory School of Medicine. Over the past year, DBMI worked closely with the Emory MathCS Department, Emory Healthcare and ACTSI to spearheadrapid development educational programs including a new Biomedical Informatics PhD track in the Computer Science and Informatics PhD program, an Informatics Masters of Science in Clinical Research, a CME granting clinical informatics educational series and a popular and well attended two day intensive informatics course aimed at health care workers and researchers. The Biomedical Informatics PhD track has been up and running for a year and will admit five new students in the coming academic year.

Under Dr. Saltz’s direction, the Center for Comprehensive Informatics (CCI) was established in 2008. CCI is dedicated to facilitating multidisciplinary projects in informatics related to integrative research, and to the recruitment to Emory of talented faculty and postdoctoral researchers. The CCI has fostered the development of multiple  collaborative research projects that span Emory, Georgia Tech, Morehouse School of Medicine and Kaiser Permanente. These projects leverage the strong  research groups across Emory to catalyze development of novel interdisciplinary efforts. CCI collaborative efforts cover a  range of fields including large scale data management and processing, techniques and tools for analyzing electronic health records, natural language processing, machine learning, high performance computing, imaging informatics, security, systems for semantic queries on spatial and temporal data, and data integrity in federated databases. These techniques and tools provide enabling translational research informatics technologies forbiomedical researchers to efficiently integrate and mine data obtained from multiple biological scales anddimensions and from multiple data sources.  This expertise has enabled the funding number of high profile strategic program grants including the newEmory Molecular Interaction Center for Functional Genomics,  the ARRA funded Minority Health Grid project and the NCI funded in Silico Center.
Research in applied math areas of controls, geometry, and topology towards multiple applications.

Education: PhD from Stony Brook University Computer Science Program with research topics in Web Metrics/Measurement, Web Performance, and Human Computer Interaction.
Experience: I interned on the Research team at Brave during Summer of 2020 under Matteo Varvello, Andrius Aunicas, and Ben Livshits. We developed a prototype for a client-side Web data-saver with the goal of increased user security and privacy. Existing approaches to save users data while browsing are limited to plain HTTP proxy, or MITM proxy approaches. These approaches either have limited reach, expose personalized page contents to third parties, or introduce additional security vulnerabilities to end-users. Instead, we optimized pages at the client through creative usage of HTTP requests, without the aid of middleboxes or past knowledge of the webpage content. Our efforts were focused on optimization of images, which make up over 44% of data costs on the median mobile webpage.
I interned at the IBM T.J. Watson research center in the Summer of 2018.

For the summer of 2017 I interned at the International Computer Science Institute (ICSI) at UC Berkeley. There I worked on the Netalyzr project under Christian Kreibich, and jointly collaborated with researchers at TUM and IMDEA. Our goal was to modernize the ICSI Netalyzr, a Java Applet based network-edge measurement tool, into JavaScript. In doing so we surveyed just what Web measurements can be done given the restrictiveness of the network stacks/security models of modern browsers. We also tackled how one might use third party JavaScript measurements within advertisement networks in order to eliminate the convenience bias associated with conventional crowd-sourced Web measurements.
